qas.question: Britain tried to influence Prussia to take what action?
How many troops did Frederick have left?
What development in Russia assisted Prussia?

answers.text: Russian Empress Elizabeth died. Her Prussophile successor, Peter III, at once recalled Russian armies from Berlin

qas.question: What changed the Prussian relationship with Sweden?

answers.text: Peter III, at once recalled Russian armies from Berlin (see: the Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1762)) and mediated Frederick's truce with Sweden

qas.question: What was the unexpected action by Peter III that helped Frederick?

answers.text: He also placed a corps of his own troops under Frederick's command

context: Britain now threatened to withdraw its subsidies if Prussia didn't consider <a0_0>offering concessions to secure peace<a0_0/>. As the Prussian armies had dwindled to just <a1_0>60,000 men<a1_0/> and with Berlin itself under siege, Frederick's survival was severely threatened. Then on 5 January 1762 the <a2_0>Russian Empress Elizabeth died. Her Prussophile successor, <a3_0>Peter III, at once recalled Russian armies from Berlin<a2_0/> (see: the Treaty of Saint Petersburg (1762)) and mediated Frederick's truce with Sweden<a3_0/>. <a4_0>He also placed a corps of his own troops under Frederick's command<a4_0/> This turn of events has become known as the Miracle of the House of Brandenburg. Frederick was then able to muster a larger army of 120,000 men and concentrate it against Austria. He drove them from much of Saxony, while his brother Henry won a victory in Silesia in the Battle of Freiberg (29 October 1762). At the same time, his Brunswick allies captured the key town of Göttingen and compounded this by taking Cassel.
